sn47.7:4.1: “Mendicants, in the Himalayas there are regions that are rugged and impassable. In some such regions, neither monkeys nor humans can go,
sn47.7:4.2: while in others, monkeys can go but not humans.
sn47.7:4.3: There are also level, pleasant places where both monkeys and humans can go.
sn47.7:4.4: There hunters lay snares of tar on the monkey trails to catch the monkeys.
sn47.7:5.1: The monkeys who are not foolish and impetuous see the tar and avoid it from afar.
sn47.7:5.2: But a foolish and impetuous monkey goes up to the tar and grabs it with a hand.
sn47.7:5.4: Thinking to free his hand, he grabs it with his other hand.
sn47.7:5.6: Thinking to free both hands, he grabs it with a foot.
sn47.7:5.8: Thinking to free both hands and foot, he grabs it with his other foot.
sn47.7:5.10: Thinking to free both hands and feet, he grabs it with his snout.
sn47.7:5.12: And so the monkey, trapped at five points, just lies there screeching. He’d meet with tragedy and disaster, and the hunter can do what he wants with it.
sn47.7:5.13: The hunter spears him, pries him off that tarred block of wood, and goes wherever he wants.
sn47.7:5.14: That’s what happens when you roam out of your territory into the domain of others.
sn47.7:6.1: So, mendicants, don’t roam out of your own territory into the domain of others.
sn47.7:6.2: If you roam out of your own territory into the domain of others, Māra will catch you and get hold of you.
sn47.7:6.3: And what is not a mendicant’s own territory but the domain of others?
sn47.7:6.4: And what is the path that helps penetration?
sn47.7:6.5: It’s the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
sn47.7:6.7: Sights cognizable by the eye that are likeable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. Sounds cognizable by the ear …
sn47.7:6.10: Touches cognizable by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
sn47.7:6.11: This is not a mendicant’s own territory but the domain of others.
sn47.7:7.1: You should roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers.
sn47.7:7.2: If you roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers, Māra won’t catch you or get hold of you.
sn47.7:7.3: And what is a mendicant’s own territory, the domain of the fathers?
sn47.7:7.5: It’s the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn47.7:7.7: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.7:7.8: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.7:7.10: principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.7:7.11: This is a mendicant’s own territory, the domain of the fathers.”
